comment:
Wait, Lex introduced this podcast with a warning of the dangers that Ai has to destroy human civilisation. And yet, Lex works in the field of artificial intelligence (AI) and machine learning (ML). He has contributed to advancing the application of Ai in society. He holds a Ph.D. in Robotics and is an adjunct professor at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT), where he has conducted research on topics such as human-robot interaction.

Both these guys are contributing to the 'destruction of human civilisation' and yet here they are being apologists!? They should be held accountable!

author: @SillyTube9

comment:
“What’s the leap between knowledge and wisdom?”

Personal risk. Something an AI can’t comprehend, because it isn’t conscious, and it doesn’t feel pain, or have a sense of a mortal self. It literally has nothing to lose.

It risks nothing in either acquiring or providing an answer. 

Wisdom is more than merely possessing a collection of facts. It’s the comprehension of what it cost to get that knowledge, and how it matters to the health of conscious creatures.

author: @samiullahk7223

comment:
Theres a point where Sam states how to deal biases. It feels kind of glossed over but its actually an incredibly powerful idea, when you think deeply on it. He basically says that the answer is to allow the user to choose how and what the biases of the model are when interacting with you. 

The reason the is a powerful solution is that it gives the user the ability to choose 'environment'. We all know about nature vs nurture. Nurture being the environment and people we surround ourselves with that changes us. If we can choose for ChatGPT to have certain characteristics and traits that we ourselves want to develop overtime, then its no longer a negative. Its a massive positive. 

We'd have to be able to trust that the ai systems behaviors and biases are actually how we wanted it to behave when we interact with it, but this could be incredibly powerful for people. 

It could become a personal mentor with the biases, behaviors, and traits that we want ourselves to have in the future. In essences it would become a sort of parental figure that we go into child mode and copy after and grow.  Again we have to have implicit trust that its behaving how the user wants it to behave.
author: @why2166

comment:
It's stupid that people find the amount of characters used to describe somebody is important. I bet, majority of these people are lazy bums, the unproductive part of society. Why? Because a regular person would understand that the amount of characters used to form a sentence or phrase majorly depends on grammar, which primarily depends on phrases/words used to describe the said character. Now it may refer to an action, hence verb, which would have different grammar settings than when used a preposition or adjective. And after all that it will also depend on perspective tone, and mood on how the specific characters are used, interpreted, arranged and described. While a machine picks randomly in all of this, without having a relative basis, it's hard to describe or understand any mood or tone, as in humans, it may depend on n number of factors. 

As well when I asked Chat GPT numerous questions limiting the character and sentence limit, it still failed to comply many a times. I guess this should be enough but for the ignorant masses counting the character rather than building up character, above paragraph should provide good explanation.
